labels.name: wontfix

issues.title: Flat collections of physical goods
issues.author: aj-stein
issues.body: This draft proposes a notion of a shipment and container at a high level. I infer from this framing you may want a "flat collection" of items shipped together (but are not nested). Will the I-D and CWT data structure address this concern?

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: The claims of this I-D are currently at the shipment/container level of granularity. If additional claims are desired that better support a "flat collection" of items shipped together, we would welcome a concrete suggestion.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: I'm not seeing a change called for in this issue and so I recommend closing it.

issues.title: Nested collections of physical goods
issues.author: aj-stein
issues.body: Related to #1 but slightly different, I infer without further detail that certain types of containers or complex shipments could be "nested" (containers within containers within containers). Will this I-D and the resulting CWT data structure within address how this could be handled by implementers?

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: The claims of this I-D are currently at the shipment/container level of granularity. If additional claims are desired that better support describing complex "nested" items shipped together, we would welcome a concrete suggestion.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: I'm not seeing a change called for in this issue and so I recommend closing it.

issues.title: IANA considers as subheading of security considerations is confusing
issues.author: aj-stein
issues.body: I know this is purely aesthetic and this I-D is early days, but it threw me off for a bit. Minor PR incoming.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: Fixed by https://github.com/mprorock/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims/commit/6db0ac4c6c0ae8b4e94c8e0e111bc17c8a250239

issues.title: Country codes: ISO 3601 alpha-1, alpha-2, or numeric?
issues.author: aj-stein
issues.body:
The current draft quickly touches on this and does not say much more. A current example is below.

> ### Origin Location
> 
> The following completed registration template per RFC8392 is provided:
> 
> Name: origin_location
> Label: TBD
> Value Type: text string
> Value Registry: (empty)
> Description: Geographical origin of the goods, represented as a location code (e.g., ISO country code) or specific address.
> Reference: RFC XXXX

I have only seen alpha-2 used in "real world deployments" (read: tools and software I work on at day job), but given this is CBOR and CWT perhaps there is an opportunity to consider the the latter because [it is adopted by the UN statistics division](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_3166_country_codes).

I am more than happy to propose a change if you have a preference for any or all, but picking one is probably good.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
Two-character strings are not very long and given the size of the other fields likely to accompany them, I don't think that using the binary country code values is worth it.

I do agree that the descriptive text could be more precise.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: Fixed by #11

issues.title: More specificy in currency codes
issues.author: aj-stein
issues.body:
Not that different from #5, we could probably afford to be more specific in this section regarding currency codes.

> 
> ### Currency Code
> 
> The following completed registration template per RFC8392 is provided:
> 
> Name: currency_code
> Label: TBD
> Value Type: text string (ISO 4217 currency code)
> Value Registry: (empty)
> Description: Currency code for the customs value and other monetary amounts, as per ISO 4217.
> Reference: RFC XXXX

Two details are worth considering:

- [ ] Like #5, there are alpha-2, alpha-3, and numeric variants of ISO-4217 it seems. The latter could be used for CBOR/CWT nature of this I-D, but I have less real world experience with that. That, or we complicate the data model for currency_code. Pick one?
- [ ] We need normative references it would seem, I can add a minor PR for that. https://github.com/mprorock/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims/pull/7

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: Per https://github.com/mprorock/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims/issues/5#issuecomment-2771609519, I don't think that the use of binary is worth it here.  Also, we're now registering JWT Claims, where the string values make more sense.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: From what I can tell from https://www.iso.org/standard/64758.html and https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217, there are not two-letter currency codes.  I'm going to create a PR specifying the use of the three-letter ones.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: Fixed by #11

issues.title: Representation of legal jurisdictions
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body:
The [Legal Jurisdiction](https://mprorock.github.io/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims.html#section-4.1.23) is currently defined as:

> Claim Name: legal_jurisdiction
> Claim Description: Legal jurisdiction(s) governing the transaction, represented as country codes or specific legal identifiers.
> JWT Claim Name: legal_jurisdiction
> Claim Key: TBD (requested assignment 342)
> Claim Value Type: text string
> Change Controller: IETF
> Reference: [Section 4.1.23](https://mprorock.github.io/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims.html#legal_jurisdiction) of this specification

Is it intended that claim may contain multiple values?  It's currently defined as a single text string.

How, for instance, would one represent that the jurisdiction is Delaware, United States or Ciudad de México?

A single [ISO.3166] alpha-2 country code string won't always work.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: Claims about jurisdiction at the level of international trade are generally expected to be at the country level, so at this point I don't think we need to support finer granularity.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: I'm not seeing a need for changes, so I recommend closing this issue.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
A change is needed to deal with there possibly being more than one legal jurisdiction.  For instance, should the value be an array?

If only one value is supported, the description needs to be made singular.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: Also, say that country codes are represented as an [[ISO.3166](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#ISO.3166)] alpha-2 country code string

issues.title: Representations of Locations
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body:
The contents of the [Origin Location](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#name-origin-location) are also somewhat ambiguous, being defined as:
> Claim Description: Geographical origin of the goods, represented as an [[ISO.3166](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#ISO.3166)] alpha-2 country code string or specific address
> Claim Value Type: text string

The [Destination Location](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#name-destination-location) is less specified than that:
> Claim Description: Final destination of the goods in the shipment.
> Claim Value Type: text string

[Last Known Location](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#name-last-known-location), [Place of Loading](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#name-place-of-loading), and [Place of Discharge](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#name-place-of-discharge) are similar.

Do we practically want these to be sufficiently specified such that different participants will put the same values in these fields?  Or are these primiarly or only for human consumption, in which case the ambiguity is acceptable?

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: For now, let's go with human consumable values.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: I'm not seeing a need for changes, so I recommend closing this issue.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: Closing for the reasons described above

issues.title: Representations of Numbers
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body:
The [Gross Weight](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#name-gross-weight) number is specified as:
> Claim Description: Gross weight of the shipment, in kilograms.
> Claim Value Type: integer

The [Temperature Min Requirement](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#name-temperature-min-requirement) is specified as:
> Claim Description: Minimum temperature (in Celsius) required for transport or storage of the goods.
> Claim Value Type: float

Five other claims also use "float".

In CBOR, it's common to allow either integer or floating point representations for numbers.  You'll see a number of claims in the [CBOR Web Token (CWT) Claims](https://www.iana.org/assignments/cwt/cwt.xhtml#claims-registry) registry using:
> Claim Value Type: integer or floating-point number

There's an argument for doing the same for all of our numeric claims, when in CBOR.

Of course, in JavaScript, all numbers are floating point, so the issue is moot for JWT claims.  Numbers are numbers there.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: Let's go with "integer or floating-point number"

issues.title: Representations of Consignee and Consignor Information
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body:
[Consignee Information](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#name-consignee-information) is defined as:
> Claim Description: Information about the consignee, including name, address, and contact details.
> Claim Value Type: map

[Consignor Information](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#name-consignor-information) parallels it.

For starters, are these maps with string-valued human-readable labels, or is there a schema we want people to use that would lend itself to a standard set of numeric labels?  If so, we could create a registry for them, with initial proposed assignments.

Are the values following the labels strings or can they be of other CBOR types?

Again, is this information primarily for human consumption, in which case the ambiguity may be OK, or do we aspire to have different participants use the fields in the same way?

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: For now, let's go with human consumable values.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: I am not seeing an action here, so I recommend closing this issue

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: Closing for the reasons described above

issues.title: Reference for Harmonized System (HS) Codes
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body: The Web is full of information about Harmonized System Codes, such as https://www.trade.gov/harmonized-system-hs-codes, but I can't be sure what the authoritative reference for them is.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: https://www.wcoomd.org/en/topics/nomenclature/overview.aspx

issues.title: Could the Exporter Code be a GLUE identifier?
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body: How does one tell now whether it's a VAT number or EORI number, for instance?

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body:
Yes, the importer_code, exporter_code, and carrier_id could all use GLUE identifiers.
Also, the consignee_information and consignor_information could contain GLUE identifiers.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body:
@selfissued which text do you prefer:

> Claim Description: Code identifying the exporter, such as a GLUE Identifier, VAT number, or EORI number.

or

> Claim Description: GLUE Identifier [GLUE] for the exporter.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: I used option a in #24, but that can be easily changed.

issues.title: Reference for International Commercial Terms
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body: What reference for [International Commercial Terms](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#name-international-commercial-te) should I use?  I ask because the example values "FOB" and "CIF" are defined somewhere.  Where is that?

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: https://iccwbo.org/business-solutions/incoterms-rules/incoterms-2020/

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: Fixed by #22

issues.title: Distinguishing between Regulatory Compliance Codes
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body: I can imagine a world of different [Regulatory Compliance Codes](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-prorock-spice-cwt-traceability-claims-01.html#name-regulatory-compliance-codes) (literally!).  How is it indicated in this field which codes are applicable and how is compliance indicated?

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: These claims are for use in representing information from trade documents in CWTs and JWTs. The only codes included in the value for regulatory_compliance_codes would be those the producer considers to be applicable, even if each recipient doesn't understand them all. For example, a credential sent to US Customs may include claims of compliance to Reg1, Reg2, and Reg3, but US Customs only cares about Reg1 and Reg3. the same credential could be sent to the US FDA, which only cares about Reg2.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
I still worry about mixing codes from different jurisdictions and not being able to tell what they actually are.  For instance, when importing avocados from Costa Rica, there may be Costa Rican codes, codes from the countries transited, and US codes.

Are we going to assume that the recipient has enough domain knowledge to figure out what is what?

issues.title: Create examples
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body:
A few illustrative examples would make the specification much more approachable.  Showing values for some of these fields would help demystify how they are intended to be used in practice.

FYI, I would do the examples as JWT claims rather than CWT claims, so readers won't have to deal with binary and we as authors won't have to deal with CDDL.

comments.author: brentzundel
comments.body: agreed
